title: White House insists Israel airstrike on Rafah did NOT cross a  red line  despite killing dozens of civilians and there is still  no major ground operation
message:
The White House on Tuesday defended U.S. ally Israel's response to the airstrike that killed dozens of civilians in Gaza, even comparing the tragic error to U.S. strikes in Iraq and Afghanistan.
'We have conducted airstrikes in places like Iraq and Afghanistan where, tragically, we caused civilian casualties,' White House national security spokesman John Kirby told reporters at the White House.
'Everything that we can see tells us that they are not moving into a major ground operation in population centers in the center of Rafah,' Kirby said.

title: Ukraine : Russia Odesa Cluster Munition Attack Harms Civilians
message:
“Russia’s cluster munition strikes on Ukraine are a case study of the grave harm posed to civilians,” said Belkis Wille, associate crisis, conflict, and arms director at Human Rights Watch.
The cluster munition attacks began in Vuhledar, followed by subsequent attacks in Kharkiv, Mykolaiv, Chernihiv, Kherson, and other cities.
The Russian cluster munition attack on the crowded Kramatorsk train station on April 8, 2022, remains one of the single deadliest incidents for civilians during the war.
“The deaths and injuries to civilians in Odesa from cluster munitions sadly won’t be the last time civilians are harmed by these weapons,” Wille said.
“Concerted international pressure is needed not only to end cluster munition use in Ukraine but throughout the world.”------------------------------------------------Click for original article...... read full story

title: Putin warns West not to let Ukraine use its missiles to hit Russia - Newspaper
message:
MOSCOW: Russian President Vladimir Putin warned the West on Tuesday that Nato members in Europe were playing with fire by proposing to let Ukraine use Western weapons to strike inside Russia, which he said could trigger a global conflict.
Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg told The Economist that alliance members should let Ukraine strike deep into Russia with Western weapons, a view supported by some European members of the transatlantic alliance but not the United States.
This is a serious thing, and we are of course watching it very closely,” Putin said.
Russian advancesRussia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022 touched off the worst breakdown in relations with the West for 60 years.
Putin casts the war as part of a struggle with the West, which he says is exploiting Ukraine as part of a wider plan to encroach on what he considers Moscow’s sphere of influence.

title: Hamas munitions likely caused fire in Rafah DP camp , says Israel
message:
Tel Aviv [Israel], May 29 (ANI/TPS): A fire at a displaced persons camp in Rafah following an airstrike was likely caused by Hamas munitions, according to a preliminary military investigation, the Israel Defense Forces said on Tuesday.
The Sunday night airstrike killed Hamas commanders Yassin Rabia and Khaled Nagar in a compound in the Rafah neighborhood of Tel Sultan.
The military believes the fire was likely caused by secondary explosions from Hamas munitions or some other material it was not aware of.
The IDF also released a recording of two Rafah residents specifically saying the fire was caused by Hamas explosives.
Israel took control of the Palestinian side of the Rafah border crossing on May 7 to prevent Hamas from commandeering humanitarian aid deliveries from Egypt.

title: Chicago police fatally shoot stabbing suspect , wound the person he was trying to stab
message:
CHICAGO — Chicago police fatally shot a stabbing suspect and wounded the person he was trying to stab after the suspect refused to drop his weapon, police said.
Officers were patrolling the city's west side about 11 p.m. Monday when they saw a male attempting to stab a male in the street and ordered the suspect to drop his weapon, police said.
When the suspect continued the attack, officers opened fire, wounding both the suspect and the victim, the Chicago Police Department said in a statement Tuesday morning.
The suspect was later pronounced dead at a hospital, and the other person was hospitalized in critical condition, police said.
The shooting occurred near the border of the Harrison and Austin police districts, two of Chicago's most violent districts, the Chicago Sun-Times reported.

title: Reports : U . N . Security Council Prepares for Another Resolution Demanding Israel Stop Fighting Hamas
message:
Multiple reports on Tuesday indicated that representatives from Algeria had prepared a draft resolution for the United Nations Security Council that would demand Israel stop its self-defense operations against the terrorist group Hamas in Gaza.
Algeria called the U.N. Security Council meeting on Tuesday and reportedly prepared a resolution calling for an immediate end to operations in Rafah.
If passed, the proposed U.N. resolution would be the second time the Security Council calls for a ceasefire in Gaza.
The IDF began its operations in northern Gaza and has since pulled into Rafah, the Gaza Strip’s southernmost city, which borders Egypt.
The airstrike prompting the proposed resolution this week reportedly killed two senior members of the Hamas “Judea and Samaria” wing, Khaled Nagar and Yassin Rabia.

The footage ultimately verified by Sky News shows numerous bodies being pulled from the wreckage of destroyed buildings.

The content of this image is as provided and cannot be independently verified.
Korean language watermark on image as provided by source reads: "KCNA" which is the abbreviation for Korean Central News Agency.

title: Russia Odesa Attack With Cluster Munition Hurts Ukraine Civilians
message:
"Russia's cluster munition strikes on Ukraine are a case study of the grave harm posed to civilians," said Belkis Wille, associate crisis, conflict, and arms director at Human Rights Watch.
Sixteen years on, 124 countries have ratified the May 30, 2008 Convention on Cluster Munitions but not Russia and Ukraine.
The cluster munition attacks began in Vuhledar, followed by subsequent attacks in Kharkiv, Mykolaiv, Chernihiv, Kherson, and other cities.
The Russian cluster munition attack on the crowded Kramatorsk train station on April 8, 2022, remains one of the single deadliest incidents for civilians during the war.
"Concerted international pressure is needed not only to end cluster munition use in Ukraine but throughout the world."

title: Nikki Haley writes  finish them  on IDF shells during Israel visit
message:
Nikki Haley signing an Israeli Defence Force shell during her visit to Israel - Howard BeckettNikki Haley wrote “finish them!” on the side of a fresh Israeli artillery shell during a visit to Israel.
Despite other politicians from both sides denouncing the country’s aggressive offensive in Gaza, including democrat and fellow Israel supporter Chuck Schumer, Ms Haley has repeatedly rushed to Israel’s defence.
On Tuesday, she visited an artillery post on the country’s northern border and wrote on a shell: “Finish them!
Nikki Haley.”Photos of Ms Haley kneeling to sign the shell were shared on social media the same day by Danny Danon, a member of the Israeli parliament who had accompanied the South Carolina govenor on her visit.
Don’t let anybody make you feel wrong because Israel is not wrong in this,” Ms Haley said in a press conference on Monday.

title: Ukraine Fires AIM - 9X Sidewinder Missiles from NASAMS
message:
Recently released footage shows an AIM-9X Sidewinder missile being fired from Ukrainian NASAMS fire unit.
Ukraine has begun using the AIM-9X Sidewinder AAM (Air-to-Air Missile) as a ground-launched AD (Air Defense) missile from the NASAMS (National Advanced Surface-to-Air Missile System), going by a promotional feature released by Ukraine recenlty.

title: Pro - Russian breakaway region Transnistria shows limits of domino theory in international relations
message:
If the Congress proceeded as planned, it’s obvious that the Transnistrian domino didn’t fall on this occasion.
Therefore, it is worth pausing to consider the limits of this metaphor and observable developments in the Transnistrian conflict.
Indeed, since the early 1960s, domino theory has faced criticism for overlooking various parameters; metaphors shape our perceptions, reinforce biases, and sometimes mask complexity, thereby exposing their limitations.
Finally, cultural and historical differences between countries can influence how ideas and events are perceived and interpreted.
In short, while Moldova might need European assistance more than ever to face up to threats of Russian destabilisation, we can’t be sure the resumption of the Transnistrian conflict is the most imminent risk.

This May half term the Imperial War Museum North is running free family activities and adventure trails through the weekIn the run up to the 80th anniversary of D-Day on June 6 the museum is hosting free drop-in activities from 10am-4pm daily until June 2.

title: Are Aircraft Carriers Still Relevant For Defense ?
message:

Naval warfare underwent a major paradigm shift from the battleship to the aircraft carrier in World War Two.

title: Netanyahu frequently makes claims of antisemitism . Critics say he deflecting from his own problems
message:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has repeatedly accused critics of Israel or his policies of antisemitism, including the U.S. college campus protests and the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court.
“Not every criticism against Israel is antisemitic,” said Tom Segev, an Israeli historian.
But his accusations of antisemitism come as he has repeatedly sidestepped accountability for not preventing Hamas’ Oct. 7 attack.
They see hypocrisy in the world's intense focus on Israel's war with Hamas while other conflicts get much less attention.
Moshe Klughaft, a former advisor to Netanyahu, said he believes the Israeli leader is genuinely concerned over rising antisemitism.

title: Ukraine - Russia war latest : French and German leaders say Ukraine allowed to strike inside Russia
message:
Ukrainian drones can strike hundreds of miles into Russia, Moscow official saysUkrainian drones have the capability of striking a target up to 1,550 miles away, but Moscow has been protected, a senior Russian airforce official has said.
"Now unmanned aerial vehicles can traverse an area of up to 2,500 kilometres, and many [Russian] regions are aware of this."
Since the start of the year, drone attacks have also struck critical oil refining infrastructure in Russia.
Ukraine does not officially confirm or deny it is attacking refineries inside Russia, but it says such sites are legitimate targets as they aid Moscow's military effort.
A major barrage in May last year saw two drones fly towards the Kremlin complex overlooking Red Square before they were destroyed.

title: Iran intervention in Sudan civil war advances its geopolitical goals − but not without risks
message:
But Tehran has received little coverage of its military intervention in another deadly conflict: Sudan’s civil war.
In the immediate aftermath of fighting breaking out between two rival factions of Sudan’s military government, Iran limited its involvement to supplying humanitarian aid.
In 2014, Sudan closed Iran’s cultural center and expelled its diplomatic officials for purportedly proselytizing Shiism in a predominantly Sunni country.
Making inroads in the HornThe civil war has provided an opportunity for Iran to correct course with Sudan.
And unlike the wars in Syria and Ukraine, in Sudan, Tehran has found itself in the awkward position of supporting an adversary of Russia, which sponsors the RSF.

title: Rafah reminds us of the evils of Hamas Why are so many in the West washing away Hamas responsibility for the Gaza catastrophe ? Brendan ONeill
message:

For some time, Hamas has been making Rafah the main base of its genocidal crusade against the Jewish State.
Harried by the IDF from the rest of the Gaza Strip, Hamas spied in Rafah a ‘safe’ site for its warmongering.
Hamas is using Rafah as a base from which to taunt, blackmail and assault the Jewish State.
When the International Court of Justice haughtily demands that Israel stay out of Rafah, it is essentially saying ‘Leave Rafah to Hamas’.

title: It was our fault …: Pakistan violated peace agreement with India in 1999 , says former Pak PM Nawaz Sharif
message:
Former Pakistan Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has admitted that his country “violated" a peace agreement with India in 1999.
This disclosure came as Sharif assumed the Pakistan Muslim League's (Nawaz) presidency, six years after being disqualified by the country's Supreme Court.
But we violated that agreement... it was our fault," Sharif said.
The agreement referred to by Sharif was the “Lahore Declaration" signed by him and then-Indian Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee on February 21, 1999.
The declaration aimed to promote peace and stability between India and Pakistan.

title: Father Jerry Pokorsky : Save Freedom of Worship
message:
Dad convinced us for many decades that his time in the Navy was like a vacation in the tropics.
The Government duplicated the original into propaganda posters for the WWII war effort.
So, the poster included these words:SAVE FREEDOM OF WORSHIP EACH ACCORDING TO THE DICTATES OF HIS OWN CONSCIENCE BUY WAR BONDSOur national authorities understood the culture our soldiers left behind and used the poster to advance the war effort.
Last year, the National Park Service denied the Knights of Columbus permission to organize a Memorial Day Catholic Mass at Poplar Grove National Cemetery in Petersburg, Virginia.
Save freedom of worship.

title: Air Force : Ukraine downs 13 Russian drones overnight
message:
Ukrainian air defenses shot down 13 of the 14 Shahed-type attack drones launched during a Russian attack overnight on May 29, according to Ukraine's Air Force Commander, Mykola Oleshchuk.
The drones were reportedly launched from the Russian port town of Primorsko-Akhtarsk, located on the coast of the Azov Sea.
The town lies approximately 153 kilometers (95 miles) from Kerch, which is located on the Crimean Peninsula that Russia annexed from Ukraine in 2014.
Aircraft, missile and electronic warfare units, and mobile fire groups of the Ukrainian Air Force intercepted the drones over Mykolaiv, Kirovohrad, and Rivne oblasts, the Air Force said in its morning update.
In recent months, Russia has intensified attacks against Ukraine's energy infrastructure, launching massive drone and missile strikes targeting critical facilities.

title: Underwater detonation of WWII - era shells closes popular beaches in southern Okinawa
message:
Japanese authorities detonate 30 World War II-era shells off Miyako Island, Okinawa, May 28, 2024.
(Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force)CAMP FOSTER, Okinawa — Japanese authorities safely detonated 30 shells believed to be left over from World War II this week on Miyakojima, a popular tourist destination 170 miles southwest of Okinawa’s main island.
The ordnance was discovered in December during dredging at Port Hirara, a hub for many ferries and cargo ships.
Popular tourist destinations, including Painagama and Sunayama beaches, where off-limits during the operation.
Approximately 10,000 tons of ordnance were dropped on Okinawa during the Battle of Okinawa and nearly 2,000 tons remain undiscovered, according to the prefecture’s General Bureau website.

title: Ancient Egyptians Tried to Surgically Treat Cancer , Study Finds
message:
The left image shows several of the metastatic lesions found on skull 236, along with suspected cutmarks.
The top right image shows skull 250, while the bottom right shows skull 236.
Scientists have discovered archaeological evidence that ancient Egyptians attempted to surgically remove cancerous lesions, pushing the practice back to over 4,000 years ago.
Skull 236 in particular was littered with tinier lesions across the skull, probably an indication of advanced, metastasized cancer.
If the team’s discovery is genuine, it would be the first documented instance of surgical cancer treatment recorded in human history.

title: Azerbaijan seeking to unite to world in war against landmines
message:
Azerbaijan is seeking partnerships to effectively combat the menace of landmines and unexploded ordinances, the country’s ambassador to Kenya Sultan Hajiyev has said.
In an interview with the Star, Hajiyev said Azerbaijan intends to use the third International Conference on Mine Action opening in Azerbaijan on May 30 to reinforce existing partnerships and establish new alliances towards achieving a mine-free world.
Azerbaijan is facing a large-scale landmine and Unexploded Ordinance (UXO) problem.
More than 200 landmine explosion incidents occurred in Azerbaijan in the last 3.5 years resulting in 359 victims, including women and children.
The Landmine Monitor Report 2023 says at least 4,710 casualties of landmines and UXO were recorded in 2022 around the world.

title: Kennedy condemns the removal of Confederate monuments
message:
Independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. speaks during the Libertarian National Convention at the Washington Hilton in Washington, Friday, May 24, 2024.
(AP Photo/Jose Luis Magana)PHOENIX (AP) — Independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has condemned the removal of Confederate statues, saying he had a “visceral reaction against" the destruction of monuments honoring southern leaders from the Civil War.
“There were heroes in the Confederacy who didn’t have slaves,” Kennedy said in response to a question about the monuments.
“And, you know, I just, I just have a visceral reaction to this destroying history.
Activists have pushed for years to remove monuments and rename buildings that honor leaders of the Confederacy, calling them symbols of racism.

message:
The Democratic Alliance of Hungarians in Romania (UDMR) and Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán’s ruling Fidesz have expressed a common hope for increased representation of “pro-peace forces” in the European Parliament, Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said on Monday.

title: At 101 , D - Day US veteran heads to France for 80th anniversary
message:
By Nathan FrandinoMARTINEZ, California (Reuters) - World War Two U.S. Army veteran Jake Larson is 101 years old and a survivor of D-Day, history’s largest amphibious invasion on June 6, 1944, and he is heading to France for the 80th anniversary to honor the brothers-in-arms who did not make it home.
Larson wears a black jacket inscribed with "WWII Survivor" and the six battles in Europe he survived including the Battle of the Bulge.
Born in the U.S. state of Minnesota, Larson joined the National Guard as a teenager before the Guard was called up at the start of World War Two.
It was under the V Corps that he was assigned to the D-Day invasion.
And now he is sharing those stories on TikTok, thanks to his granddaughter who started the account for him during the pandemic.

(Yonhap)North Korea's botched attempt to launch a military spy satellite was likely due to its difficulties in procuring related parts and developing technology because of ongoing sanctions, a presidential official said Wednesday.
North Korea made a failed attempt to launch a space rocket carrying a reconnaissance satellite hours after leaders of South Korea, Japan and China met in Seoul on Monday for a summit, the first since December 2019.

title: North Korea Accused of Floating Poo Balloons Into the South
message:
South Korea’s military on Wednesday accused North Korea of floating balloons loaded with trash and manure across the border and immediately demanded that Pyongyang halt its “inhumane and vulgar” operation.
More than 260 balloons have already been detected in South Korea since the operation began on Tuesday night, South Korea’s Joint Chiefs of Staff said.
Images released by the military appear to show the balloons carrying plastic bags—one of which had the word “excrement” written on the side, according to Reuters.
“These acts by North Korea clearly violate international law and seriously threaten our people’s safety,” the JCS said, adding a stern warning to “North Korea to immediately stop its inhumane and vulgar act.”The balloons started arriving days after Kim Kang Il, North Korea’s vice defense minister, slammed propaganda leaflets criticizing the Pyongyang regime that North Korean defectors in the South have been attaching to balloons and sending northward for years.
“Mounds of wastepaper and filth will soon be scattered over the border areas and the interior of [South Korea] and it will directly experience how much effort is required to remove them,” he said.

title: Wilmington Whiskey Run returns June 15 | News , Sports , Jobs - Adirondack Daily Enterprise

The 5K and 10K races begin at 9:30 a.m., followed by the Whiskey Run Festival from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at Preston Festival Field located at 2 Cunningham Lane.

During Tuesday’s White House press briefing, O’Keefe grilled Kirby about the current situation and Biden’s previous admonitions to Israel about Rafah:O’KEEFE: How does this not violate the red line that the president laid out?

title: Hamas Terrorists Fire At Israeli Community On Green Line
message:
Terrorists affiliated with Hamas recorded themselves shooting toward Bat Hefer on Wednesday morning.
The video clip lasting less than a minute shows three terrorists with their faces covered and blurred, wearing the trademark green bandana representing Hamas.
The community, which lies on the Israeli side of the Green Line demarcating the West Bank border, sits opposite to Tulkarm which is known as a hotbed of terrorist activity.
Transportation for school children was relocated to the opposite side of the community and accompanied by army patrols.
This is the second incident in the week in which the community came under threat, with dozens of terrorists approaching the West Bank security barrier.

message:

This is the same line that was picked by the suspected Zanu PF youths who disrupted the hearings as they shouted that the amendments would “curb terrorism”.
Public hearings emanated from the 1999 recommendations of the Parliamentary Reform Committee that emphasised, among others, the “need for a more effective, open, responsive and responsible Parliament”.
According to Parliament, public hearings are meant to inform the public and interested parties about proposed changes and implications of public policy; obtain public views and recommendations on public policy programmes; facilitate an appreciation of government policies and legislation and, therefore, reduce or eliminate chances of difficulty in policy implementation.

title: Honoring the Valor
message:
In the face of relentless adversity, the Pakistan military has shown an unyielding commitment to combating terrorism, often at great personal cost.
These brave men will be laid to rest with full military honors in their respective native towns, a testament to their valor and dedication.
Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Governor Faisal Karim Kundi also expressed his condolences, highlighting the nation’s gratitude for the sacrifices made by the security forces.
The steadfastness and professionalism of the Pakistan military have been pivotal in thwarting these threats.
In remembering and honoring their sacrifices, Pakistan reaffirms its resolve to fight against terrorism and work towards a future of peace and stability.

title: Kosovo prepares to house 300 inmates from Denmark , raising human rights concerns
message:
Denmark is expected to send 300 inmates to the Balkan country, a first for Kosovo and a move highly criticized by Danish human rights experts.
The eight-year-old jail itself doesn’t raise human rights concerns, but the decision to house inmates in Kosovo does, said Therese Rytter, legal director of Dignity, a Danish human rights organization.
A Danish prison governor will co-manage the facility with a local director, while all guards will be local.
The Kosovar prison guards will receive training from Danish authorities to ensure treatment of inmates meet Danish and international human rights standards, the Danish justice ministry said.
But Danish human rights experts are not convinced.

title: Rosmah bid to involve police and government in lawsuit over missing jewellery fails
message:
KUALA LUMPUR: Datin Seri Rosmah Mansor has failed in her bid to bring the police and the government as third parties into a US$14.57mil lawsuit against her over missing jewellery pieces at the High Court.
Rosmah, however, was at liberty to initiate a separate civil lawsuit for any alleged losses suffered from the authorities' actions regarding the jewellery.
During the in-chamber proceedings here on Wednesday (May 29), lawyer Venothani Rajagopal appeared for the plaintiff Global Royalty Trading SAL, while Senior Federal Counsel Syafiq Affandy appeared for the police and the government.
Global Royalty also claimed that Rosmah had shifted the burden to the Malaysian government when the jewellery had gone missing.
Rosmah said companies like Global Royalty sought publicity for their products and wanted her to be their customer.

title: Town votes overwhelmingly in favor of flying Progress Pride flags
message:
The residents of Williamstown, Massachusetts voted 175-90 to pass a bylaw allowing the Progress Pride flag to be flown on town flag poles.
The vote occurred at a city board meeting and comes at a time when other cities have banned rainbow-colored Pride flags being flown from government buildings.
In March, the residents in Huntington Beach, California voted to ban Pride flags on city property.
However, many cities allow their government spaces to fly the Pride flag.
In January, the town of Norwich, Ontario in Canada voted to reverse its Pride fag ban.

message:
The Association of Bureau De Change Operators of Nigeria has demanded that the Central Bank of Nigeria reverse the new capital requirement for its operations.
The BDC operators, at the end of a virtual meeting themed ‘New CBN Regulatory & Supervisory Reforms for BDCs: Challenges and Way Forward’ on Tuesday, decried the move by the CBN.
Existing BDCs to be allowed to use their generic names as against registration of new names at the CAC.
